awd_abstract_narration:
Minimal surfaces are physical objects that appear in mathematics and  applied science, where for instance they are used to model black holes or tensile structures. Intuitively, minimal surfaces are shapes that are in some equilibrium position (like soap films for example), which can be either stable or unstable.  Over the last years immense progress has been done regarding the existence of unstable minimal surfaces and their qualitative behavior as the degrees of instability increase.  Many questions which were open for a long time have just been settled and this project plans to continue that investigation further.  This project is also expected to continue the training of graduate students in this active area, as well as research seminars and conferences.
 
This project plans to continue exploring the variational theory of minimal surfaces. Several problems are proposed where the common theme is that the analogous question for geodesics follows from the fact that geodesics are closed orbits of an Hamiltonian flow. This perspective does not have a direct analogue in minimal surface theory and hence its interest. The PI will study asymptotic properties of the minimal hypersurfaces as their degrees of instability increase and also the properties of minimal surfaces of large area when the ambient space is negatively curved. The project involves combination of Morse theory, variational methods, geometry, and topology.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Minimal surfaces represent shapes in a state of equilibrium and are significant in various applied sciences, making their properties an important area of mathematical study. Fundamental questions regarding minimal surfaces focus on their existence within closed manifolds, the number of such surfaces, their asymptotic behavior, and the extent to which the ambient space's metric structure is reflected by these surfaces.

The guiding philosophy behind the NSF grant DMS 2005468 was to advance the theory of existence while exploring new directions in the study of minimal surfaces. Specifically, the grant aimed to investigate the growth properties of minimal surfaces in negatively curved spaces and the possibility of codimension-one Zoll metrics on spheres. While analogous questions for closed geodesics have been effectively addressed through the Hamiltonian properties of geodesic flow, this approach is not applicable to minimal surfaces, which are fundamentally variational in nature. This distinction adds considerable interest to the problem.

As a result of this award, the Principal Investigator (PI) authored four papers published in leading mathematics journals. One notable paper, titled "Counting Minimal Surfaces in Negatively Curved 3-Manifolds," pioneered a new direction in the examination of minimal surfaces in these settings. This work was featured in a Bourbaki seminar, and two of the subsequent papers further expanded on this study. Among other contributions, the PI introduced the concept of minimal surface entropy and demonstrated its relationships with scalar curvature and other classical entropies, including Liouville entropy.

The remaining paper, "Riemannian Metrics on the Sphere with Zoll Families of Minimal Hypersurfaces," initiated a novel construction of metrics designed to maximize the number of minimal hypersurfaces. This research lays the groundwork for exploring manifolds that possess as many minimal hypersurfaces as a round sphere.

During the grant period, the PI graduated four doctoral students. Three of these students progressed to postdoctoral positions at prestigious research institutions in the United States, while the fourth accepted a position in the industry sector.

The PI organized three workshops, two of which were held in the USA, and presented his research at over 20 conferences across North America, Europe, and Asia.
